marketNews.title: Uncertainty Over HGBT Incentive and Its Impact on Gas‑Intensive Industries
marketNews.content:
The Chairman of the Association of Ceramic Industry (Asaki), Edy Suyanto, said that there is still no continuation regarding the specific natural gas price incentive (HGBT) worth USD 6.5 per MMBtu, which ended on 31 December 2024. According to a report by Tempo, the termination of the HGBT policy caused the price of gas used below the industrial gas allocation limit (AGIT) to rise from USD 6.5 per MMBtu to a commercial price above USD 10 per MMBtu.

Edy also stated that Perusahaan Gas Negara (PGAS) increased the surcharge for industries using gas above the AGIT by +21.08%, from USD 13.85 per MMBtu to USD 16.77 per MMBtu for the period 1 January–31 March 2025.

Edy explained that the HGBT incentive initially reduced the gas cost component from 28‑30% of total ceramic production costs to a level of 23‑26%. However, gas supply disruptions in West and East Java since 2023, together with the surcharge of USD 13.85 per MMBtu that has been in place since May 2024, have pushed the gas cost component back above 30% of ceramic production costs.

Edy has sent a letter to President Prabowo Subianto to save the national ceramic industry after foreign investors in Asaki said they would halt investment due to legal uncertainty. PGAS has not commented on the surcharge or the gas supply disruption.

Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said on Friday (3 January) that the HGBT incentive is under evaluation. In December 2024, Acting Director General of Oil and Gas, Dadan Kusdiana, signaled that the HGBT policy would be continued in 2025 at a similar price, around USD 6 per MMBtu. Dadan also said the ministry received a recommendation from the Ministry of Industry to add 15 new sub‑sectors as HGBT recipients. Previously, HGBT recipients were limited to seven sectors: ceramics, fertilizer, petrochemicals, oleochemicals, steel, glass, and rubber gloves.

Key Takeaway: PGAS could enjoy higher margins with the end of the HGBT incentive in early 2025 and the surcharge increase. Conversely, higher gas prices will negatively affect industries with a high gas‑energy cost component, although the impact is expected to be short‑term as the HGBT policy is still under government discussion.

Based on the market close on Monday (6 January), PGAS shares rose +7.52%, while several gas‑sensitive stocks moved mixed: $TPIA (‑5.23%), $ARNA (‑1.45%), $MARK (‑0.46%), $AMFG (+1.16%), $CAKK (+1.34%).

marketNews.title: Patrick Walujo Commits to Remain GOTO President Director Until 2029 and Related Corporate Updates
marketNews.content:
GoTo Gojek Tokopedia announced that Patrick Sugito Walujo is committed to remain as the company's President Director until 2029. Patrick Walujo has held the President Director position since June 2023.

Chief Corporate Communication & Corporate Secretary of Adaro Andalan Indonesia, Ray A. Singgih, said the company targets thermal coal production of 65.5 million tonnes in 2025, which is 5.6‑7.4% higher than the 2024 target of 61‑62 million tonnes set by Alamtri Resources Indonesia (formerly ADRO).

Meratus Jasa Prima’s controlling shareholder, PT Saranakelola Investa, sold approximately 4.7 million KARW shares at an average price of IDR 2,434 per share on 27 December 2024, totaling about IDR 11.4 billion, to broaden retail investor ownership. After the transaction, PT Saranakelola Investa’s stake in KARW fell from 79.48% to 78.68%.

Pemberton Asian Opportunities Fund, a shareholder of Sarimelati Kencana (PZZA), bought 32 million PZZA shares at IDR 113 per share on 3 January 2025, totaling about IDR 3.6 billion. After the transaction, its stake rose from 6.95% to 8.01%.

Multi Medika Internasional announced a memorandum of understanding for a joint venture to build a diaper factory in Tangerang, Banten with Chinese company Fujian Nicepaper Hygiene Products Co. Ltd. (Nice Paper). The value of the cooperation has not been disclosed and will be negotiated.

Wintermar Offshore Marine (WINS) said it targets fleet utilization of 75% in 2025, up from 68% in 2024, as several drilling projects in Indonesia have not yet started, such as the Masela and Andaman blocks. The company also aims to raise vessel charter rates by about +10‑15% in 2025 due to limited offshore support vessel supply. Expansion plans for 2025 were mentioned but details on the number of vessels and capex were not disclosed.

United Tractors and its subsidiary PT Pamapersada Nusantara announced an increase in the equity stake of its energy subsidiary PT Energia Prima Nusantara (EPN) by IDR 2.97 trillion. The corporate action also led to a further IDR 40 billion increase in the stake of PT Bina Pertiwi Energi, intended for additional working capital.

Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa (INTP) said it will continue a joint project with Amita Group to establish a company that will produce fuel and alternative materials for supply to cement and other companies. INTP will allocate IDR 1 trillion in capex in 2025 (versus a 2024 allocation of IDR 1.2‑1.5 trillion), despite an oversupply of more than 50 million tonnes per year in the cement market. To protect profitability, INTP will continue efficiency efforts, including a 50% acquisition of PT Samudra Harmoni Prakarsa in December 2024.

Nusantara Sawit Sejahtera (NSSS) shareholder Indo Alam Resources Pte. Ltd. sold about 365 million NSSS shares at an average price of IDR 105 per share on 30 December 2024, totaling about IDR 38 billion. After the transaction, its stake fell from 5.91% to 4.38%.

On Friday, 3 January 2025, Stockbit Snips reported that Sido Muncul (SIDO) targeted low‑single‑digit revenue and net‑profit growth, which was later corrected to low‑double‑digit growth.

Finance Minister Sri Mulyani announced on Monday (6 January) that the 2024 state budget deficit reached 2.29% of GDP, matching the original target but higher than the 2023 realization of 1.61% of GDP. The result was also lower than the Ministry of Finance’s September 2024 projection of a 2.7% deficit.

The government plans to issue eight series of retail government securities (SBN) in 2025 as a financing instrument for the 2025 budget and a fixed‑income option for the public: ORI027 (27 Jan‑20 Feb), ST014 (7 Mar‑16 Apr), SR022 (16 May‑18 Jun), SBR014 (14 Jul‑7 Aug), SWR006 (15 Aug‑15 Oct), SR023 (22 Aug‑12 Sep), ORI028 (29 Sep‑23 Oct), ST015 (10 Nov‑3 Dec).

Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia announced on Friday (3 January) that the government will allocate 15.62 million kiloliters of biodiesel to implement the mandatory B40 blend in 2025, up from an estimated 12.98 million kiloliters for the mandatory B35 in 2024. Of the 2025 allocation, 7.55 million kiloliters are for public‑service‑obligation and will be subsidised by the Palm Oil Plantation Fund, with the remainder sold at market price. Director General Eniya Listiani Dewi said producers and fuel retailers have until 28 February 2025 to implement B40. Bahlil added that Indonesia will move to a B50 blend in 2026, which he claims will end the need for imported diesel.

SKK Migas Chairman Djoko Siswanto said the 2025 oil lifting target is 605 kilo‑barrels per day (vs. 596.4 kbo/d in 2024) and gas lifting target is 1,005 kbo/d (vs. 991 kbo/d in 2024), in line with the 2025 budget. SKK Migas has not announced 2024 lifting results. However, an outlook released in mid‑2024 projected 2024 oil lifting at 595 kbo/d and gas lifting at 993 kbo/d.

The Directorate General of Taxes issued Director‑General Regulation No. PER‑01/PJ/2025 to address excess VAT collection. The regulation allows buyers to claim a 1‑percentage‑point refund of excess VAT from sellers, with the taxable entrepreneur providing a replacement tax invoice. Previously, the government’s decision to cancel the effective VAT rate for general goods and services, which raised the rate from 11% to an erroneously collected 12%, caused the excess‑VAT case.

The Institute for Supply Management reported that the U.S. manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reached 49.3 in December 2024 (vs. 48.4 in November 2024), beating the consensus of 48.4. Although still in contraction, it was the best U.S. manufacturing PMI since March 2024’s 50.3, the only expansion period since September 2022.

Freeport Indonesia’s spokesperson Katri Krisnati said the company is discussing with the government the possible relaxation of copper concentrate exports so that the JIIPE, Gresik smelter can operate at full capacity again. The smelter burned in October 2024, prompting Freeport to seek an extension of the export‑relaxation that expired at the end of 2024. Katri said repairs are ongoing and production is expected to resume around mid‑2025. Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the government is considering the request and will decide in a meeting with President Prabowo Subianto.

Humpuss Maritim Internasional (HUMI) through its subsidiary PT Hutama Trans Kencana announced the lease of one oil‑chemical tanker from PT Pelayaran Maritim Hijau at USD 5,490 per month. The lease runs for five years with an option to purchase for USD 1.5 million at the end of the lease term.

marketNews.title: IHSG Decline 1.17% on 6 January 2025
marketNews.content:
The Indonesian Stock Exchange (IHSG) fell 1.17% on 6 January 2025.

Key market summary: The Jakarta Composite Index (IHSG) closed down 1.17% on the day.

tickerNews.title: PGAS Increases Surcharge for Above‑AGIT Gas Use
tickerNews.content: Perusahaan Gas Negara (PGAS) increased the surcharge for industries using gas above the industrial allocation limit (AGIT) by +21.08%, raising the surcharge from USD 13.85 per MMBtu to USD 16.77 per MMBtu for the period 1 January–31 March 2025.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Shares Drop 5.23% on 6 January 2025
tickerNews.content: $TPIA shares fell 5.23% on the market close on 6 January 2025.
